) To carry out its duties regarding investigations of counterfeiting and forgery, U.S. Secret Service has requested that the Service supply information (follow IRM

) above to transmit the information): a. That regards the counterfeiting of U.S. or foreign obligations, i.e., coins, stamps, bonds, U.S. Treasury checks, Treasury securities, Depart- ment of Agriculture food coupons, debit cards and postage stamps. b. That relate to the forgery, alteration and fraudulent negotiation of U.S. Treasury checks and U.S. Government bonds. (

) There is ongoing contact between U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) and the Service. Programs cover two areas: a. Aliens legally admitted to the U.S. b. Aliens who entered the U.S. illegally (
) Returns and return information are conﬁdential pursuant to IRC
Disclo- sure of returns or return information to USCIS is statutorily authorized only in very limited circumstances; if such disclosure is contemplated, contact the closure Office. See IRM
, Disclosure of Official Information, for on the disclosure of returns and return information. (
) Certain programs ensure that nonresident aliens who are authorized by to enter the U.S., are aware of federal tax requirements and are meeting obligations. (

) Other efforts are geared to aliens who have entered the country illegally and are apprehended by USCIS. Many of the illegal aliens are paid low wages have limited tax potential. However, those illegal aliens apprehended with the potential for signiﬁcant tax liabilities are referred to IRS. (

) Occasionally, revenue officers may need information that an immunized witness was compelled to supply under a grant of immunity from This immunity can be granted by: • Congressional Committees • Certain federal and state agencies • Courts • Grand juries (

) Information that is directly or indirectly derived from evidence or testimony which an immunized witness was compelled to supply cannot be used that witness in a criminal tax case now or in the future. Caution: To ensure that any criminal tax case against an immunized witness is inadvertently jeopardized, revenue officers must exercise caution when they:
Obtain compelled information.
Maintain compelled information in Collection case ﬁles.

) Prepare a memorandum to the Criminal Investigation (CI), Director, Field erations and forward it through the Field Territory Manager. The Officer will state: for a. What information is needed, Compelled b. Who has the information, and c. Why it is needed for a case. (
) With the advice of Criminal Tax Counsel, the CI Director, Field Operations respond to the request by: a. Approving, b. Disapproving, or c. Placing limitations on the request. (

) Compelled testimony and other information may not be used in any other action during the pendency of the criminal aspects of the investigation express written consent of the Director, Field Operations. (
) If a prosecution referral to the Department of Justice is in effect, the rence of the Tax Division must be obtained prior to the non-injunctive civil of the testimony or information. (

All information developed through unrelated, independent investigation Compelled also identiﬁable and segregated from the compelled information. c. ) Maintain a chronological record of all Service personnel who had access to compelled information in any open case ﬁle. (
) Revenue officers who have access to compelled information should not be subsequently assigned to any joint criminal investigation on the witness furnished it. (

) The Federal Employee/Retiree Delinquency Initiative (FERDI) program was developed in

by the Internal Revenue Service to promote federal tax compliance among current and retired federal employees. The program incor- porates the purpose and intent of Office of Government Ethics regulation
Initiative C.F.R.

which addresses the responsibility of federal employees to “satisfy in good faith their obligations as citizens, including all just ﬁnancial gations, especially those such as federal, state, or local taxes that are by law.” The following section contains instructions for handling federal employee and retiree delinquencies. (

) The procedures in this section apply to all taxpayers currently receiving a salary or pension from the federal government. This includes the following: • Civilian employees, including U.S. Postal Service • Civil Service or Federal Employee Retirement System retirees • Active duty military • Military retirees • National Guard/Reservists
The procedures in this section apply to all taxpayers currently receiving a salary or pension from the federal government. This includes the following:
Note: These procedures do not apply to survivors of federal

Interview procedures for these taxpayers are the same as for any other taxpayer: use the tiered interview to obtain full payment and ﬁling of returns today, or the best arrangement you can get. However, other procedures are different for federal employees and retirees, and are outlined in this section. FERDI taxpayers are identiﬁed by matching the primary Social Security Number (SSN) and secondary SSN (if joint liability) of balance due and/or return delinquency accounts against: • U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM) Central Personnel Data (CPDF) • Department of Defense military and civilian personnel records Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC) • U.S. Postal Service (USPS) employment ﬁle • Selected internal Form W-
, Wage and Tax Statement, records Systemic Master File processing of the matched records generates a tion code (TC)

with Document Locator Number (DLN) (where “y” is the last year digit of the year the DLN was assigned). This action will cause a FERDI indicator to be set on the Individual Master File(IMF). The FERDI indicator may also be manually set by input of TC AC

The FERDI indicator is an entity indicator. On joint accounts, the FERDI indicator posts to the primary SSN, regardless of whether the primary, the secondary, or both taxpayers are federal employees or retirees. Our computer systems display the indicator by the following literals: • IDRS IMF ENMOD screen: FED-EMP>F • ICS Case Summary Screen: FED • IDRS TDINQ: SELECTION CODE

A military POA is sufficient authorization to permit an individual to represent a deployed member of the military before the IRS.

An individual holding a military POA is often the spouse of the deployed military member. Since the military POA is broader and cannot be input into the CAF, it is acceptable for the IRS to require the non-deployed spouse (or other military POA holder) to complete a Form
, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative. The spouse (or other military POA holder) should be permitted to sign the Form
for the military member and as deployed military member’s authorized representative. See IRM
, Military Power of Attorney (POA) for Representation of Deployed Military Personnel.
A Form 2848 signed by the military member and his or her authorized repre- sentative, including a spouse or other family member, is sufficient for representation before the IRS.
